Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 46310  
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
August 2013 
 
 
 
Promoting Regional Knowledge Sharing Partnerships 
(Financed by the People’s Republic of China Regional Cooperation 
and Poverty Reduction Fund) 
 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 12 August 2013)

CNY1.00  =  $0.16334 
$1.00  =  CNY6.12190

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—Capacity development technical assistance (R-CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Public sector management (economic and public affairs 
management; public expenditure and fiscal management)  
Themes (subthemes)   –  Capacity development (institutional development; 
organizational development; client relations, network, and 
partnership development); economic growth (promoting 
economic efficiency and enabling business environment; 
knowledge, science, and technological capacities); environmental 
sustainability (environmental policy and legislation); regional 
cooperation and integration (cross-border infrastructure; other 
regional public goods)

Reduction Fund

Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2

External Relations

designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

CONTENTS 
 
   Page 
 
I.  INTRODUCTION                                                                                                              1 
II.  ISSUES  1 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  3 
  A.   Impact and Outcome                                                                         3 
  B.  Methodology and Key Activities                                                         3 
  C.  Cost and Financing                                                                            4 
  D.  Implementation Arrangements                                                            4 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION                                        5 
 
APPENDIXES 
1.   Design and Monitoring Framework                                                                  6 
2.   Cost Estimates and Financing Plan                                                                 9 
3.   Outline Terms of Reference for Consultants                                           10 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Through South–South cooperation and knowledge exchange, developing countries with 
extensive development experience and effective practices can contribute to the formulation of 
relevant, effective, and efficient solutions to development challenges. The Busan Declaration of 
2011 recognized that “South–South and triangular co-operation have the potential to transform 
developing countries’ policies and approaches to service delivery by bringing effective, locally 
owned  solutions  that  are  appropriate  to  country  contexts.”  It  further  encouraged  “the 
development of networks for knowledge exchange, peer learning and co-ordination among 
South–South co-operation actors as a means of facilitating access to important knowledge 
pools by developing countries.” 
 
2.  To  promote  South–South  cooperation, the Government  of  the  People’s  Republic of 
China (PRC) and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) established the Regional Knowledge 
Sharing Initiative (RKSI) on 30 August 2012. The RKSI—located at ADB’s PRC resident mission 
in Beijing—is mandated to foster South–South knowledge sharing, which is intended to increase 
collaboration among developing countries and promote regional cooperation and integration. 
The RKSI provides a platform for knowledge exchange among ADB’s developing member 
countries  (DMCs),  promotes  regional  knowledge  sharing  events  that  build  on  knowledge 
partnerships,  and  is  intended  to  serve  as  catalyst  for  sharing  knowledge  generated  by 
developing countries.  
 
3.  The technical assistance (TA) will support the identification, development, and sharing of 
knowledge solutions in DMCs consistent with ADB’s Strategy 2020 and country partnership 
strategies  (CPSs)  covering  the  DMCs  concerned.1 The  TA  will  work  closely  with  partner 
institutions in the PRC and other DMCs, with ADB as a knowledge intermediary. 
 
4.  The TA will be implemented through the RKSI and will facilitate the development of 
knowledge  sharing  events  with  key  partner  institutions  in  the  PRC  and  other  DMCs;  the 
production  of  high-quality  knowledge  products;  and  the  strengthening  and  expansion  of 
knowledge sharing networks and partnerships among key DMC institutions.2 The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES  
5.  ADB’s Strategy 2020 highlights knowledge solutions as one of the five drivers for change 
that will propel development in Asia and the Pacific. Knowledge solutions are identified in 
numerous CPSs as a driver of change in individual DMCs. For example, the PRC CPS for 
2011–2015 highlights the role that knowledge sharing can play by developing and promoting 
best practices and scaling up demonstration projects.3 Successful development solutions in one 
country can be highly applicable in another. 
 
6.  ADB is supporting knowledge sharing by developing platforms for knowledge exchange 
in  key  sectors  and  thematic  areas.  Knowledge  cooperation  is  being  developed  by  both 
operational departments and specialized knowledge departments. For example, in May 2012, a 
Knowledge Sharing and Services Center was established in the Regional and Sustainable 
Development Department to connect and coordinate the different knowledge sharing platforms.  
                                                
1  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 31 July 2013. 
3  ADB. 2012. Country Partnership Strategy: People’s Republic of China, 2011–2015. Manila.

2   
 
7.  In ADB’s operational departments, knowledge management has become an integral part 
of both country-level operations and regional cooperation and integration. In middle-income 
countries in particular, there is an increased emphasis on generating knowledge from loan and 
TA operations and sharing this knowledge with other DMCs. Drawing knowledge solutions from 
ADB operations helps to ensure their practical relevance.   
 
8.  There are numerous internationally competitive universities and think tanks in the region, 
and  ADB  is  working  with  many  of  them  through  TA  grants,  loan  projects,  and  capacity 
development programs. In some DMCs, ADB has established dedicated knowledge hubs or 
knowledge partnerships based on specific sectors and themes. Some knowledge partnerships 
are project-based and designed to deliver a specific knowledge product, while others have been 
initiated to support knowledge generation more broadly. For example, in the PRC, the Urban 
Knowledge Hub, which was established in March 2010 with Tongji University in Shanghai, is 
sharing best practice approaches in urban planning. Knowledge hubs provide a venue for 
regular knowledge exchange, serve as an entry point for identifying resource persons and 
consultants, and assist in generating knowledge solutions and new project ideas.             
 
9.  The RKSI builds on previous knowledge cooperation between ADB and the PRC to 
further  develop  South–South  knowledge  sharing.4 The  annual  event  under  the  ADB–PRC 
knowledge sharing platform is now coordinated  through the RKSI. The RKSI is based on 
triangular cooperation that promotes South–South cooperation through mutual learning and the 
sharing of development experiences between the PRC and other DMCs, with ADB playing an 
intermediary role.5  
 
10.  The  RKSI  is  intended  to  (i)  organize  and  co-partner  demand-based  international 
knowledge  sharing  events;  (ii)  produce  knowledge  products  based  on  these  events;  and 
(iii) strengthen existing knowledge networks, assist in forming new ones, and assist—together 
with other ADB departments—in linking with other ADB-wide knowledge partnerships. The RKSI 
operates in close collaboration with ADB regional cooperation initiatives such as the Greater 
Mekong Subregion and Central Asia Regional economic cooperation programs.  
 
11.  For knowledge cooperation to be effective, it is essential to work closely with local 
institutions in DMCs. The RKSI was established in the PRC resident mission so that it could 
work  closely  with  local  institutions,  cooperate  with  these  institutions  in  building  up  their 
knowledge sharing programs, and assist these institutions in building up their networking and 
partnerships with knowledge institutions in other DMCs. The RKSI will help initiate or build up 
these partnerships, which are expected to become self-sustaining in the longer term.  
 
                                                
4  Previous knowledge sharing was carried out under the ADB–PRC knowledge sharing platform. Events organized 
under  the  platform  included  “Sustainable  Urbanization,”  Shanghai,  PRC,  2–6  November  2009;  “Transport 
Infrastructure:  An  Instrument  for  Economic  and  Social  Development,”  Beijing,  PRC,  8–11  November  2010; 
“Agricultural and Rural Development: Improving Farm Productivity and Rural Livelihoods,” Beijing, PRC, 8–11 
November 2011; and “South–South Knowledge Cooperation,” Manila, Philippines, 13 September 2012. 
5  Triangular cooperation is a collaboration between a developing or “southern” (sometimes called pivotal) provider 
and a developed country or multilateral organization for the benefit of a third receiving country or group of 
countries. A common feature is that know-how, skills, experiences, and resources from North and South are 
combined.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The  impact  of  the  TA  will  be  strengthened  and  sustained  knowledge  sharing  and 
cooperation among the PRC and other DMCs through triangular cooperation. The outcome of 
the TA will be the strengthened capacity of key institutions and knowledge networks in the PRC 
and other DMCs to address emerging issues and challenges in the region effectively through 
knowledge sharing.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The  TA  will  work  through  key  knowledge  institutions  in  the  PRC  and  their  partner 
institutions in other DMCs to enhance the development and use of knowledge solutions. The 
RKSI has a coordination  role to facilitate knowledge sharing  with and among ADB’s PRC 
knowledge partnerships and knowledge hubs, and is currently working closely with the Asia-
Pacific Finance and Development Center, International Poverty Reduction Center for China, 
Ministry  of  Environmental  Protection,  Urban  Knowledge  Hub  at  Tongji  University,  and 
International Enterprise Singapore to develop international knowledge sharing events.  
 
14.  The business model of the TA and of the RKSI more broadly, is to serve as a catalyst for 
promoting knowledge sharing in the region, particularly the development of knowledge sharing 
networks. The TA will support the RKSI in establishing initial knowledge sharing activities with 
the aforementioned partner institutions in the PRC, and in building up cooperation between 
these institutions, with partner institutions in other DMCs, and with other development partners. 
In the initial phase, as supported by the TA, the RKSI will provide catalytic and co-financial 
support for knowledge sharing activities jointly organized by institutions in the PRC and other 
DMCs. Subsequently, financial support from the RKSI would be supplemented or replaced by 
financing from the partner institutions and/or from other development partners.  
    
15.  The outputs of the TA will include (i) international knowledge sharing workshops, (ii) 
knowledge products, (iii) networks that foster mutual learning  through the sharing of good 
practices  and  lessons  learned from  the  PRC and  other  DMCs,  (iv)  a  website to  enhance 
interaction and knowledge sharing, and (v) development of the RKSI strategy and medium-term 
workplan.  The  workshops  will  produce  knowledge  products,  including  background/seminar 
papers,  workshop  proceedings,  related  brochures,  and  multi-language  video  clips  on  key 
knowledge solutions.  
 
16.  Output 1: International knowledge sharing workshops completed. A minimum of 
four demand-based international knowledge sharing workshops will be implemented in 2013 
and  2014.  In  each  workshop,  key  practitioners  and  decision  makers  will  discuss  selected 
knowledge solutions, which will be followed by an international array of discussants exploring 
linkages to their respective countries. There will be a strong focus on adapting and replicating 
knowledge  solutions  from  other  countries.  The  knowledge  sharing  workshops  will  be  built 
around existing partnerships in the PRC, and they will subsequently expand to include partner 
institutions in other DMCs. The TA will primarily provide support for resource persons and 
international participants. 
 
17.  Output 2: Knowledge products produced and disseminated. Each workshop will 
produce knowledge products, including workshop papers, workshop proceedings and other 
publications, and multi-language video clips. As part of the workshops exhibitions and related

4   
brochures may also be developed. The TA will support the development, production, translation, 
and dissemination of high-quality knowledge products to ensure broad access to participants 
from different DMCs.    
  
18.  Output 3: Networks that foster mutual learning strengthened and expanded. The 
TA will help key institutions expand institutional knowledge partnerships, linking them with each 
other to build on synergies in knowledge sharing.6 Many DMC institutions have strong networks 
with domestic institutions, but limited international contacts with institutions in other DMCs. The 
TA, through knowledge sharing activities and support from ADB, which has many existing 
partnerships throughout  the region,  will  help  partner  institutions  build up  their  international 
networks.   
 
19.  Output 4: RKSI website developed. The TA will develop an RKSI website based on a 
website business plan closely developed with ADB’s Department of External Relations. The 
website will serve as a depository of knowledge products of RKSI events and related South–
South knowledge products and networks. The website will also contain interactive elements to 
allow for broad-based interaction with knowledge partners and stakeholders. 
 
20.  Output 5: RKSI strategy and medium-term workplan developed. The TA will support 
the development of the RKSI strategy and the medium-term workplan based on the evaluation 
of the first 15 months of RKSI operations.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
21.  The TA is estimated to cost $600,000. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the 
People's  Republic  of  China  Regional  Cooperation  and  Poverty  Reduction  Fund  and 
administered by ADB. The Government of the PRC endorsed financing of the TA on 20 June 
2013 and may consider further financing in subsequent years. The Government of the PRC will 
provide  in-kind  contributions,  including  counterpart  staff,  and  other  participating  DMCs  will 
provide various counterpart activities and support for the organization of knowledge sharing 
activities.  Events  will  be  further  leveraged  by  other  ADB  resources  or  by  cofinancing 
arrangements. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
22.  ADB will be the executing agency, with the East Asia Department as the focal point. The 
RKSI will coordinate and work closely with other ADB regional and specialized knowledge 
departments,  and  it  will  provide  quarterly  progress  reports  to  the  fund.  The  TA  will  be 
implemented between 26 August 2013 and 25 March 2015. 
 
23.  The  TA  will  engage  individual  international  consultants  for  10  person-months  and 
individual  national  consultants  for  8  person-months.  ADB  will  recruit  the  consultants  in 
accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). 
The TA will also finance regional knowledge sharing activities, including resource persons, 
international participants, and the preparation and finalization of knowledge products developed 
in connection with these events. All procurement under the TA will be carried out in accordance 
with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2013, as amended from time to time). After implementation 
of the TA, all procured items will remain with the executing agency. The TA will be disbursed in 
                                                
6  ADB. 2011. Guidelines for Knowledge Partnerships. Manila.

5 
accordance with Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time 
to time).  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the People's Republic of China Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction 
Fund for the Promoting Regional Knowledge Sharing Partnerships, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

10   Appendix 3          
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.  Senior Communication Specialist (5 person-months, international, intermittent) 
 
1.  The  senior  communication  specialist  shall  have  more  than  5  years  expertise  in 
communicating scientific research topics to broad audiences. The specialist will report to the 
Regional Knowledge Sharing Initiative (RKSI) coordinator. The candidate should preferably be 
based in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). Tasks are as follows: 
(i)  Summarize the content of all workshop presentations and background papers to 
be used for one coherent publication on the respective workshop. 
(ii)  Edit presented papers and other workshop material to be uploaded to the RKSI 
website. 
(iii)  Assist in the production of other publication types (website pages, audience-
targeted flyers and brochures). 
(iv)  Write storylines for 5–10 minute multimedia productions in close coordination 
with the videographer.    
 
B.  Videographer (2 person-months, international, intermittent) 
 
2.  The videographer shall have more than 10 years of international experience filming and 
producing documentary-length as well as short-form human interest pieces. The videographer 
will  report  to  the  RKSI  coordinator  and  shall  work  closely  together  with  the  senior 
communication specialist and the multimedia specialist. The candidate should preferably be 
based in the PRC. The final terms of reference will follow the guidelines developed by the 
Department of External Relations of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). Tasks are as follows: 
(i)  Develop knowledge video concept together with RKSI staff and the Department 
of External Relations. All knowledge solution videos must be 5–10 minutes in 
length. 
(ii)  Produce  RKSI  knowledge  videos,  including  storyboard  conceptualization, 
interviews, interview transcription, script writing, and supervision of the video 
editor during editing and post-production.  
(iii)  Supervise  production  and  post-production  services,  including  field  production 
filming,  narration  supervision  and  recording,  off-line  editing,  musical  scoring, 
audio  lay-in,  audio  sweetening,  mixing  and  re-stripping,  visual  and  graphic 
design, production and lay-in of graphics and titles, on-line editing, addition of 
digital  video  effects,  video  insert  editing,  and  standards  conversion  where 
necessary. 
 
C.  Multimedia Specialist (2 person-months, national, intermittent) 
 
3.  The  multimedia  specialist  shall  have  proven  background  in  multimedia  productions 
mainly using open source software. The specialist will report to the RKSI coordinator and work 
closely together with the senior communication specialist and the videographer. Tasks are as 
follows: 
(i)  Develop an RKSI format for all visuals (e.g. PowerPoint presentations). 
(ii)  Enhance and/or develop PowerPoint slides to be used for video production and 
for  conference  proceedings  using  catchy  presentation  software  (gapminder, 
infographics, etc.). 
(iii)  Build visualization aids based on global information systems and maps in line 
with ADB requirements.

Appendix 3  11 
 
D.  Website Developer (3 consultants, 2 person-months total, national)  
 
4.  The website developer will have proven background in developing websites according to 
Department  of  External  Relations  standards.  The  website  developer  will  work  under  the 
guidance  of  the  RKSI  coordinator  in  close  cooperation  with  the  Department  of  External 
Relations, and should follow the initial RKSI website site map (Figure 1). 
 
Figure 1: RKSI Website Site Map 
 
 
Source: Asian Development Bank.  
 
5.  The website developer will perform the following tasks:  
(i)  Upload conference information, including updates, agendas, objectives, and 
logistics, divided into conference-specific subsites. 
(ii)  Upload conference presentations. 
(iii)  Upload reference materials, including source publications, infographics, reports, 
studies, factsheets, briefs, policy documents, guidelines, research papers, 
agreements, and training materials. 
(iv)  Upload videos and photos related to hosted conferences and topics. 
(v)  Create links to relevant websites, documents, multimedia, articles, and projects. 
(vi)  Upload profiles of contributing speakers, registered users, and conference 
participants. 
(vii)  Upload opinion pieces (blogs) by selected contributors.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
 
E.  Senior Urban Planner (2 person-months, international) 
 
6.  The senior urban planner shall assist knowledge events conducted together with the 
Tongji Urban Knowledge Hub. The planner shall have at least 10 years of experience in urban 
planning. The planner will report to the RKSI coordinator in close coordination with the Tongji 
Urban Knowledge Hub. Tasks are as follows: 
(i)  Develop  a  technical  concept  for  an  urban  planning  interactive  website.  The 
website shall feature lessons learned from the past decades of urban planning in 
the PRC by showcasing urban development plans and their implementation. The 
main  target  group  will  be  developing  countries,  but  will  also  include  urban 
planning practitioners.    
(ii)  Incorporate comments of the peer-reviewed concept and incorporate them into 
the revised technical concept. 
(iii)  Coordinate with the website developer to implement the approved concept.  
   
 
F.  Strategy Advisor (1 person-month, international) 
 
7.   The strategy advisor shall have at least 10 years experience in developing strategies for 
corporate and/or public companies and/or public institutions. The strategy advisor will report to 
the RKSI coordinator. Tasks are as follows: 
(i)  Develop  assessment  criteria  for  the  RKSI  by  taking  in  account  mandate, 
resources, RKSI workplan among others. Conduct the assessment accordingly.   
(ii)  Conduct stakeholder consultations (e.g., PRC government agencies, knowledge 
partnerships) 
(iii)  Develop RKSI strategy together with a medium-term workplan.
